member.name: T:NLog.Internal.LogEventInfoBuffer
member.summary: A cyclic buffer of object.

member.name: M:NLog.Internal.LogEventInfoBuffer.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: Whether buffer should grow as it becomes full.
The maximum number of items that the buffer can grow to.

member.name: M:NLog.Internal.LogEventInfoBuffer.Append(NLog.LogEventInfo)
member.summary: Adds the specified log event to the buffer.
member.returns: The number of items in the buffer.

member.name: M:NLog.Internal.LogEventInfoBuffer.GetEventsAndClear
member.summary: Gets the array of events accumulated in the buffer and clears the buffer as one atomic operation.
member.returns: An array of objects that have been accumulated in the buffer.
member.remarks: In case there are no items in the buffer, the function returns an empty array.

member.name: P:NLog.Internal.LogEventInfoBuffer.Size
member.summary: Gets the number of items in the array.

member.name: T:NLog.LayoutRenderers.AspNetApplicationValueLayoutRenderer
member.summary: ASP.NET Application variable.
member.remarks: Use this layout renderer to insert the value of the specified variable stored in the ASP.NET Application dictionary.

example.para: You can set the value of an ASP.NET Application variable by using the following code:
example.code: ${aspnet-application:variable=myvariable} - produces "123" ${aspnet-application:variable=anothervariable} - produces "01/01/2006 00:00:00" ${aspnet-application:variable=anothervariable:culture=pl-PL} - produces "2006-01-01 00:00:00" ${aspnet-application:variable=myvariable:padding=5} - produces " 123" ${aspnet-application:variable=myvariable:padding=-5} - produces "123 " ${aspnet-application:variable=stringvariable:upperCase=true} - produces "AAA BBB"

member.name: M:NLog.LayoutRenderers.AspNetApplicationValueLayoutRenderer.Append(System.Text.StringBuilder,NLog.LogEventInfo)
member.summary: Renders the specified ASP.NET Application variable and appends it to the specified .
member.param: The to append the rendered data to.

member.name: P:NLog.LayoutRenderers.AspNetApplicationValueLayoutRenderer.Variable
member.summary: Gets or sets the variable name.

member.name: T:NLog.LayoutRenderers.AspNetRequestValueLayoutRenderer
member.summary: ASP.NET Request variable.
member.remarks: Use this layout renderer to insert the value of the specified parameter of the ASP.NET Request object.

member.name: M:NLog.LayoutRenderers.AspNetRequestValueLayoutRenderer.Append(System.Text.StringBuilder,NLog.LogEventInfo)
member.summary: Renders the specified ASP.NET Request variable and appends it to the specified .
member.param: The to append the rendered data to.

member.summary: Gets or sets the item name. The QueryString, Form, Cookies, or ServerVariables collection variables having the specified name are rendered.

member.summary: Gets or sets the QueryString variable to be rendered.

member.name: T:NLog.Targets.AspNetTraceTarget
member.summary: Writes logging messages to the ASP.NET trace.
member.example:
To set up the ASP.NET Trace target in the configuration file, put the following in web.nlog file in your web application directory.
This assumes just one target and a single rule. More configuration options are described here.
To configure the target programmatically, put the following piece of code in your Application_OnStart() handler in Global.asax.cs or some other place that gets executed at the very beginning of your code:
Fully working C# project can be found in the Examples/Targets/Configuration API/ASPNetTrace directory along with usage instructions.
Resulting log entries can be viewed by navigating to http://server/path/Trace.axd.
HTTP Request List:
HTTP Request Details:

member.name: M:NLog.Targets.AspNetTraceTarget.Write(NLog.LogEventInfo)
member.summary: Writes the specified logging event to the ASP.NET Trace facility. Log entries can then be viewed by navigating to http://server/path/Trace.axd If the log level is greater than or equal to it uses the method, otherwise it uses method.

member.name: T:NLog.Targets.MessageQueueTarget
member.summary: Writes log message to the specified message queue handled by MSMQ.

example.p: To set up the target in the configuration file, use the following syntax:
You can use a single target to write to multiple queues (similar to writing to multiple files with the File target).
The above examples assume just one target and a single rule. More configuration options are described here.
To set up the log target programmatically use code like this:

member.name: M:NLog.Targets.MessageQueueTarget.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.remarks: The default value of the layout is: ${longdate}|${level:uppercase=true}|${logger}|${message}

member.name: M:NLog.Targets.MessageQueueTarget.Write(NLog.LogEventInfo)
member.summary: Writes the specified logging event to a queue specified in the Queue parameter.

member.name: M:NLog.Targets.MessageQueueTarget.PrepareMessage(NLog.LogEventInfo)
member.summary: Prepares a message to be sent to the message queue.
member.param: The log event to be used when calculating label and text to be written.
member.remarks: You may override this method in inheriting classes to provide services like encryption or message authentication.

member.name: P:NLog.Targets.MessageQueueTarget.Queue
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the queue to write to.
member.remarks: To write to a private queue on a local machine use .\private$\QueueName. For other available queue names, consult MSMQ documentation.

member.name: P:NLog.Targets.MessageQueueTarget.Label
member.summary: Gets or sets the label to associate with each message.
member.remarks: By default no label is associated.

member.name: P:NLog.Targets.MessageQueueTarget.CreateQueueIfNotExists
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to create the queue if it doesn't exists.

member.name: P:NLog.Targets.MessageQueueTarget.Encoding
member.summary: Gets or sets the encoding to be used when writing text to the queue.

member.name: P:NLog.Targets.MessageQueueTarget.UseXmlEncoding
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to use the XML format when serializing message.

member.name: P:NLog.Targets.MessageQueueTarget.Recoverable
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to use recoverable messages (with guaranteed delivery).

member.name: T:NLog.Targets.Wrappers.AspNetBufferingTargetWrapper
member.summary: A target that buffers log events for the duration of the ASP.NET Request and sends them down to the wrapped target as soon as the request ends.

remarks.p: Typically this target is used in cooperation with PostFilteringTargetWrapper to provide verbose logging for failing requests and normal or no logging for successful requests. We need to make the decision of the final filtering rule to apply after all logs for a page have been generated.
To use this target, you need to add an entry in the httpModules section of web.config:

example.p: To set up the ASP.NET Buffering target wrapper configuration file, put the following in web.nlog file in your web application directory (this assumes that PostFilteringWrapper is used to provide the filtering and actual logs go to a file).
This assumes just one target and a single rule. More configuration options are described here.

To configure the target programmatically, put the following piece of code in your Application_OnStart() handler in Global.asax.cs or some other place that gets executed at the very beginning of your code:
Fully working C# project can be found in the Examples/Targets/Configuration API/ASPNetBufferingWrapper directory along with usage instructions.

member.name: M:NLog.Targets.Wrappers.AspNetBufferingTargetWrapper.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:NLog.Targets.Wrappers.AspNetBufferingTargetWrapper.#ctor(NLog.Targets.Target)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:NLog.Targets.Wrappers.AspNetBufferingTargetWrapper.#ctor(NLog.Targets.Target,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:NLog.Targets.Wrappers.AspNetBufferingTargetWrapper.Initialize
member.summary: Initializes the target by hooking up the NLogHttpModule BeginRequest and EndRequest events.

member.name: M:NLog.Targets.Wrappers.AspNetBufferingTargetWrapper.Close
member.summary: Closes the target by flushing pending events in the buffer (if any).

member.name: M:NLog.Targets.Wrappers.AspNetBufferingTargetWrapper.Write(NLog.LogEventInfo)
member.summary: Adds the specified log event to the buffer.

member.name: P:NLog.Targets.Wrappers.AspNetBufferingTargetWrapper.BufferSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of log events to be buffered.

member.name: P:NLog.Targets.Wrappers.AspNetBufferingTargetWrapper.GrowBufferAsNeeded
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether buffer should grow as needed.
member.value: A value of true if buffer should grow as needed; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: Value of true causes the buffer to expand until is hit, false causes the buffer to never expand and lose the earliest entries in case of overflow.

member.name: P:NLog.Targets.Wrappers.AspNetBufferingTargetWrapper.BufferGrowLimit
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of log events that the buffer can keep.

member.name: T:NLog.Web.NLogHttpModule
member.summary: ASP.NET HttpModule that enables NLog to hook BeginRequest and EndRequest events easily.

member.name: M:NLog.Web.NLogHttpModule.Init(System.Web.HttpApplication)
member.summary: Initializes the HttpModule.

member.name: M:NLog.Web.NLogHttpModule.Dispose
member.summary: Disposes the module.

member.name: E:NLog.Web.NLogHttpModule.EndRequest
member.summary: Event to be raised at the end of each HTTP Request.

member.name: E:NLog.Web.NLogHttpModule.BeginRequest
member.summary: Event to be raised at the beginning of each HTTP Request.
